emergency
Procedures</strong></h2
faq
what
is
the
difference
between
lockdown
and
shelter
in
place
lockdown
and
shelter
in
place</strong>?</span></p
if

have
heard

terms

in
place
and
lockdown
and
been

to
what
the
difference
is
do

worry

are
not
alone
the
distinction
is
not
necessarily

it
is
important
both
are
instructions
to

between
you
and
threat
the
difference
is
in

types

and
what

barrier
is
called
for.</p
lockdown</span></span></strong></span></span></span></span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span
may
be
instructed
during
situations
such
as
hostile
or
armed
intruder
inside
building
lockdown
requires
locking
doors
and
windows
and
barricading
oneself
to
block
entry
to
facility
or
to
an
office
suite.&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p
shelter
in
place</span></span></strong></span></span></span></span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span
is
the
use
of
structure
and
its

atmosphere
to

from
hazardous
outdoor
atmosphere
this
can
be
because

or
weather

emergency
it
entails

all
doors
windows
and
vents

needs.</p
same

Clinic</strong></h3

that

women

contraception

non

Statement</strong></h1
the
universitys&nbsp;<a
href="https://policy.arizona.edu
human
resources
nondiscrimination
and
anti
harassment
policy">nondiscrimination
and
anti
harassment
policy</a>&nbsp;prohibits
discrimination
on
the
basis
of
race
color
religion
sex
national
origin
age
disability
veteran
status
sexual
orientation
gender
identity
or
genetic
information
title
ix
of
the
educational
amendments
of
protects
individuals
from
discrimination
based
on
sex
in
any
educational
program
or
activity
operated
by
recipients
of
federal
financial
assistance.</p
as
required
by
title
ix
the
university
of
arizona
does
not
discriminate
on
the
basis
of
sex
in
its
educational
programs
or
activities
including
in
admission
and
employment.</p
inquiries
concerning
the
application
of
title
ix
may
be
referred
to
the
universitys
title
ix
coordinator
or
to
the
u.s.
department
of
education
assistant
secretary
or
both.&nbsp;please
contact&nbsp;<a
href="mailto
equity@arizona.edu">equity@arizona.edu</a>&nbsp;or
for
more
information.&nbsp;</p

new
study
unveils
16,000
years
of
climate
history
in
the
tropical
andes
brown
university</title
august
juan
siliezar
new
study
unveils
16,000
years
of
climate
history
in
the
tropical
Andes</h1
brown
led
researchers
highlight
16,000
years
of
climate
history
in
the
tropical
andes
which
includes
areas
like
the
laguna
llaviucu
in
cajas
national
park
in
ecuador
photos
by
mark
bush
providence
r.i.</strong
brown
university
new
study
that
explores
ancient
temperatures
and
rainfall
patterns
in
the
tropical
andes
of
south
america
has
revealed
how
16,000
years
of
climate
history
in
this
part
of
the
world
was
driven
by
carbon
dioxide
levels
and
ocean
currents
from
global
climate
events.</p
led
by
brown
university
researchers
the
study
marks
the
first
high
resolution
temperature
record
covering
the
past
16,000
years
in
the
tropical
andes
and
could
help
scientists
predict
and
mitigate
future
climate
impacts
in
tropical
regions
of
the
planet
the
work
is
in
the
proceedings
of
the
national
academy
of
science.</p
usually
when
we
study
climate
change
in
the
past
we
emphasize
the
northern
hemisphere
or
southern
hemisphere
because
of
the
outsized
role
they
play
in
affecting
climates
all
over
the
globe
said
boyang
zhao
scientist
in
browns
department
of
earth
environmental
and
planetary
sciences
and
the
studys
first
author
one
of
the
biggest
questions
we
are
getting
at
is
what
are
the
driving
factors
behind
temperature
history
in
this
part
of
the
tropics
so
that
we
can
begin
to
potentially
apply
that
data
and
knowledge
to
other
tropical
regions.</p
along
with
future
implications
the
new
study
provides
unique
look
at
the
way
distinct
and
distant
parts
of
the
world
influence
temperature
and
weather
elsewhere
emphasizing
how
regional
climates
are
connected
to
global
climate
changes.</p
our
evidence
here
suggests
that
temperatures
in
this
region
of
the
world
are
more
influenced
by
the
southern
hemisphere
so
places
like
antarctica
zhao
said.</p
the
study
focused
on
an
analysis
of
sediment
samples
from
laguna
llaviucu
lake
located
in
ecuadors
cajas
national
park
the
measurements
from
the
sediment
samples
showed
that
temperature
variations
in
the
tropical
andes
closely
aligned
with
climate
events
that
saw
the
planets
temperatures
rise
and
fall
during
the
past
16,000
years.</p
overall
the
evidence
showed
that
the
main
driver
in
these
temperature
fluctuations
was
the
concentration
of
CO2
researchers
saw
evidence
that
the
tropical
andean
temperatures
track
with
antarctic
temperatures
which
are
mainly
controlled
by
carbon
dioxide
concentrations
the
findings
showed
that
about
17,000
to
14,000
years
ago
tropical
andean
temperatures
rose
when
carbon
dioxide
increased
and
that
the
temperatures
remained
relatively
stable
about
12,000
years
ago
when
carbon
dioxide
levels
remained
relatively
stable.</p
zhao
said
that
the
findings
support
previous
research
identifying
carbon
dioxide
as
key
driver
of
global
temperature
changes
since
the
last
ice
age.</p
the
study
also
highlighted
the
role
of
ocean
currents
that
move
warm
water
from
the
tropics
to
the
north
atlantic
during
cooling
period
known
as
the
antarctic
cold
reversal
14,500
years
ago
the
northward
current
was
strengthened
causing
it
to
transport
more
heat
northward
and
cool
sea
surface
temperatures
in
the
south
the
researchers
found
that
this
cooling
effect
extended
to
the
tropical
andes.</p
to
reconstruct
past
climate
conditions
the
researchers
analyzed
lipid
biomarkers
and
hydrogen
isotopes
collected
in
from
laguna
llaviucu
by
scientist
mark
bush
from
the
florida
institute
of
technology
lipid
biomarkers
are
chemical
compounds
that
provide
clues
about
past
temperatures
and
rainfall
patterns
the
high
resolution
data
combined
with
accurate
dating
techniques
allowed
the
team
to
create
detailed
timeline
of
climate
changes
over
the
past
16,000
years.</p
according
to
the
researchers
this
is
the
first
time
organic
biomarkers
have
been
used
to
put
together
quantitative
climate
history
for
tropical
south
america
it
is
traditionally
difficult
to
reconstruct
temperatures
from
the
tropics.</p
the
study
also
points
out
number
of
regional
differences
in
temperature
patterns
like
how
the
tropical
andes
and
southeast
asia
cooled
during
certain
historical
periods
while
other
regions
like
africa
did
not.<strong
the
research
also
shows
how
local
factors
may
help
to
counteract
the
global
effects
of
rising
CO2
levels
by
looking
at
differences
between
past
temperature
models
and
what
the
sediment
data
show.</p
the
researchers
from
brown
plan
to
continue
to
explore
past
temperature
patterns
in
this
part
of
the
world
that
historically
lacks
complete
climate
records.</p
mountain

second

medieval
Cultures</h1
medieval
cultures</strong
focuses
on
the
6th-15th
centuries
combining
interdisciplinary
perspectives
with
in
depth
study
of
one
or
two
related
disciplines.</p
late
antique
cultures</strong
deals
with
the
3rd-9th
centuries
when
ancient
cultural
forms
were
still
in
place
but
medieval
cultures
were
beginning
to
take
shape
simultaneously
the
first
undergraduate
degree
of
its
kind
in
this
country
late
antique
cultures
studies
the
changing
relation
of
cultural
practices
social
patterns
political
and
economics
forms
and
artistic
and
literary
traditions
in
this
important
transition
period.</p
traditional
area
of
study
in
medieval
cultures
is
western
europe
in
the
high
middle
ages
but
students
are
encouraged
to
work
comparatively
in
byzantine
islamic
judaic
and/or
slavic
cultures
in
the
middle
ages.</p

robert

amp

carney
institute
for
brain
Science</a></h1
search</span></a></li
search</span></a></li
accelerating

and

visitor
parking
visitors
may
find
parking
in
lot
upper
also
called
the
power
street
parking
garage
located
at
power
street
the
garage

is
located
at
the
intersection

power
and
thayer
streets
the
garage
has
two
gate
arms
which
are
left
open
please
enter
in
the
right
lane
and
exit
via
the
left
lane.</p
the
lot
upper
garage
contains
two
pay
stations
which
are
located
at
the
front
and
rear
of
the
garage
please
locate
an
empty
parking
space

your
visitor

permit

and

your
receipt

your
vehicle

duration</strong></th
rate</strong></th
the
pay
stations
accept
credit
cards
and
u.s.
bills

pay

not

of
bills

allow
plenty

time
for
parking
as
the
visitor
lot
is

from
the
campus
center.</p
brown
maintains
visitor
spaces
that
meet
ada

for

in
lot
which
is

south

street

brook

state
ada

ada

if

upper

full

streets

and
around

maximum

please

tuition
and
aid
brown
university</title
tuition
and
Aid</h1
undergraduate
students
if
brown
is
for
you
we
'll
help
you
get
here
our
generous
financial
aid
initiatives
are
designed
to
enrich
our
campus
community
by
ensuring
that
no
student
who
belongs
at
brown
will
encounter
cost
as
barrier.</p
how
do
we
do
this
we
meet
percent
of
each
student
's
demonstrated
financial
need
and
we
do
this
with
no
loans
only
scholarship
grants
included
in
university
financial
aid
packages
this
is
the
brown
promise</em
the
latest
in
long
series
of
initiatives
to
make
brown
increasingly
affordable
to
students
and
families
from
all
socioeconomic
backgrounds.</p
graduate
students
brown
's
graduate
programs
share
in
the
university
's
overall
commitment
to
enrolling
talented
students
from
every
background
doctoral
students
are
offered
five
years
of
guaranteed
financial
support
including
stipend
tuition
remission
health
services
fee
and
health-
and
dental

cognitive
linguistic
amp
psychological
sciences
centers
amp
Initiatives</h1
carney
institute
for
brain
science
the
as
one
of
its
core
missions
the
institute
is
developing
and
supporting
series
of
interdisciplinary
research
centers
that
focus
on
established
or
emerging
areas
of
excellence
in
brain
research
at
brown
each
center
bridges
the
physical
and
life
sciences
and
encompasses
basic
and
translational
research
including
clinical
application.<a
href="http://cvr.brown.edu
aboutcvr.html
rel="nofollow">the
center
for
vision
research</a
was
created
in
initiatives
in
neurotechnology
and
in
synaptic
and
neurodegenerative
disease
are
underway
carney
institutehas
also
established
an
mri
research
facility
and
an
behavioral
analysis
core
facility
the
existence
of
brain
science
as
an
overall
organizing
entity
for
series
of
research
centers
and
core
facilities
demonstrates
the
university
's
ongoing
support
for
brain
science
research
at
brown
this
commitment
will
help
to
attract
top
faculty
and
students
to
brown
enable
higher
quality
research
and
establish
brown
as
worldwide
leader
in
brain
science
brown
initiative
for
computation
in
brain
and
mind
computational
methods
have
been
enormously
productive
for
understanding
complexities
inherent
in
natural
systems
from
the
weather
to
aerodynamics
physics
and
biology
the
brain
is
perhaps
the
most
complex
and
interesting
of
these
systems
the
problem
of
understanding
the
relationship
between
brain
and
mind
is
so
immensely
complex
that
close
interaction
among
theorists
and
experimentalists
is
required
to
gain
deeper
understanding
of
fundamental
brain
and
cognitive
processes
because
of
the
many
levels
spanning
from
molecules
to
cognition
multiple
levels
of
computer
simulations
from
those
focused
on
details
of
neuronal
function
to

focused
on
the
abstract

that
emerge
from
these

can
be

applied
to
bridge
this
gap
brown
's
is
place
where
these

regularly
occur
across
faculty

and
across

at
all
levels
data
science
initiative
browns

science
initiative
dsi

cross

core
foundational
departments
applied
mathematics
biostatistics
computer

of
data

society

andsocial
justice

centered
robotics

ultimately

life
at
Brown</h1
brown
's
mission
to
advance
knowledge
and
discovery
benefits
from
the
presence
of
an
intellectually
stimulating
mix
of
voices
and
ideas
we
are
teaching
and
learning
community
grounded
in
respect
for
the
views
of
others
even

especially
when
we
disagree.</p
that
mix
of
perspectives
and
commitment
to
respect

with
the
innovative
dynamic
spirit

the
university
's
distinctive
open
curriculum

life
at
brown
in
settings
that
range
from
academic
to
residential
to

members

brown
communitycollaborate
on
pioneering

innovative
startups
artistic
performance
and
social

travel

and
partner
with
community
organizations
to

brain

applied

russian

sanford

providence
r.i.
dark

is

ca

global

highly

into
wimps

for
comprising
dark
matter
short
for
weakly
interacting
massive
particles
wimps
ca

be
seen
because
they
do
nt
absorb

reflect

they
interact

normal
matter
only

rare

so

detect

when
millions
may
be
traveling
through

earth
and
everything
on
it
each
second.</p
after

of

from

lux
zeplin
lz
dark

detector

for
these

exploring
weaker

interactions
than

the
key

that

for
wimp
signals
above
mass
of
9gigaelectronvolts
c2
measurement
roughly
equivalent

proton

brain
computer
interface
allows
man
with
als
to
speak
again
brown
university</title
august
juan
siliezar
brain
computer
interface
allows
man
with
als
to
speak
again</h1
the
new
bci
system
allowed
casey
harrell
year
old
person
with
als
to
communicate
his
intended
speech
effectively
within
minutes
of
activation
photo
provided
by
university
of
california
regents
providence
r.i.</strong
brown
university
scientists
with
the
research
consortium
have
developed
brain
computer
interface
that
translates
brain
signals
into
speech
with
up
to
accuracy
offering
significant
breakthrough
for
individuals
with
speech
impairments
due
to
conditions
like
amyotrophic
lateral
sclerosis.</p
the
technology
involves
using
implanted
sensors
in
the
brain
to
interpret
brain
signals
when
user
attempts
to
speak
these
signals
are
then
converted
into
text
which
is
read
aloud
by
computer.</p
the
work
is
described
in
new
study
in
the
new
england
journal
of
medicine
published
on
wednesday
aug.
that
was
led
by
neurosurgeon
david
brandman
and
neuroscientist
sergey
stavisky
both
of
whom
are
brown
university
alumni
and
faculty
members
at
uc
davis
health.</p
our
bci
technology
helped
man
with
paralysis
to
communicate
with
friends
families
and
caregivers
brandman
said
our
paper
demonstrates
the
most
accurate
speech
neuroprosthesis
ever
reported.</p
als
also
known
as
lou
gehrig
's
disease
affects
nerve
cells
controlling
muscle
movement
leading
to
the
gradual
loss
of
mobility
and
speech
bci
technology
aims
to
restore
communication
for
those
who
have
lost
the
ability
to
speak
due
to
paralysis
or
neurological
disorders.</p
the
system
allowed
casey
harrell
year
old
person
with
als
to
communicate
his
intended
speech
effectively
within
minutes
of
activation
the
powerful
moment
brought
tears
to
harrell
and
his
family
harrell
reflecting
on
his
experience
with
the
technology
described
the
impact
that
regaining
the
ability
to
communicate
could
have
on
others
facing
similar
challenges.</p
not
being
able
to
communicate
is
so
frustrating
and
demoralizing
it
is
like
you
are
trapped
harrell
said
something
like
this
technology
will
help
people
back
into
life
and
society.</p
the
first
time
harrell
tried
the
system
he
cried
with
joy
as
the
words
he
was
trying
to
say
correctly
appeared
on
screen
photo
provided
by
university
of
california
regents
the
study
is
part
of
the
braingate
clinical
trial
directed
by
dr.
leigh
hochberg
critical
care
neurologist
and
professor
at
brown
universitys
who
is
affiliated
with
the
universitys
casey
and
our
other
braingate
participants
are
truly
extraordinary
hochberg
said
they
deserve
tremendous
credit
for
joining
these
early
clinical
trials
they
do
this
not
because
they
re
hoping
to
gain
any
personal
benefit
but
to
help
us
develop
system
that
will
restore
communication
and
mobility
for
other
people
with
paralysis.</p
it
is
the
latest
in
in
brain
computer
interfaces
made
by
the
braingate
consortium
which
along
with
other
work
using
bcis
has
been
developing
systems
for
several
years
that
enable
people
to
generate
text
by
decoding
the
users
intent
last
year
the
consortium
described
how
brain
computer
interface
they
developed
enabled
clinical
trial
participant
who
lost
the
ability
to
speak
to
at
rates
that
approach
the
speed
of
regular
speech
just
by
thinking
of
saying
the
words.</p
the
field
of
brain
computer
interface
has
come
remarkably
far
in
both
precision
and
speed
said
john
ngai
director
of
the
national
institutes
of
healths
brain
research
through
advancing
innovative
neurotechnologies</em
initiative
the
brain
initiative)</a
which
funded
earlier
phases
of
the
braingate
consortium
this
latest
development
brings
technology
closer
to
helpingpeople
locked
in
by
paralysis
regain
their
ability
to
communicate
with
friends
and
loved
ones
and
enjoy
the
best
quality
of
life
possible.</p
in
july
the
team
at
uc
davis
health
implanted
the
bci
device
consisting
of
four
microelectrode
arrays
into
harrells
left
precentral
gyrus
brain
region
responsible
for
coordinating
speech
these
arrays
record
brain
activity
from
cortical
electrodes
and
detect
their
attempt
to
move
their
muscles
and
talk.</p
we
are
recording
from
the
part
of
the
brain
that
trying
to
send
these
commands
to
the
muscles
stavisky
said
we
are
basically
listening
into
that
and
were
translating
those
patterns
of
brain
activity
into
phoneme
like
syllable
or
the
unit
of
speech
and
then
the
words
they
re
trying
to
say.</p
bci
allows
man
to
039;speak
new
brain
computer
interface
translates
brain
signals
into
speech
with
up
to
accuracy
the
most
accurate
system
of
its
kind
the
study
reports
on
data
collection
sessions
over
weeks
in
total
harrell
used
the
speech
bci
in
self
paced
conversations
for
over
hours
to
communicate
in
person
and
over
video
chat
the
system
showed
decoded
words
on
screen
and
read
them
aloud
in
voice
synthesized
from
harrells
pre
als
voice
samples.</p
in
the
first
session
the
system
achieved
word
accuracy
with
word
vocabulary
in
just
minutes
in
another
session
with
vocabulary
expanded
to
125,000
words
the
system
achieved
accuracy
after
an
additional
hours
of
training
data
after
continued
data
collection
the
bci
has
maintained
accuracy.</p
at
this
point
we
can
decode
what
casey
is
trying
to
say
correctly
about
of
the
time
which
is
better
than
many
commercially
available
smartphone
applications
that
try
to
interpret
persons
voice
brandman
said
this
technology
is
transformative
because
it
provides
hope
for
people
who
want
to
speak
but
cant.</p
the
research
included
funding
from
thenational
institutes
of
health.</p
this
story
was
adapted
from
published
by
nadine
yehya
at
uc
davis
health.</em></p

science

ba
in

Science</h1
Contact</h3
for
contact
information
please
visit
the
bu
marine
program
the
ba
in
marine
science
offered
through
the
bu
marine
program
bump
provides
rigorous
interdisciplinary
education
in
marine
science
with
courses
in
biological
chemical
geological
and
physical
oceanography
all
marine
science
majors
complete
the
marine
semester
an
intellectually
and
physically
challenging
sequence
of
four
month
long
research
based
courses
during
the
marine
semester
students
conduct
research
in
variety
of
new
england
locations
as
well
as
the
belizean
barrier
reef
working
with
bu
faculty
and
scientists
from
the
new
england
aquarium
noaa
and
the
university
of
belize.</p
the
ba
in
marine
science
prepares
graduates
for
marine
related
positions
in
commercial
educational
governmental
and
nonprofit
organizations
and
for
admission
to
graduate
school
in
range
of
fields
e.g.
environmental
science
and
policy
marine
biology
oceanography
etc.).</p
learning
Outcomes</h2
the
marine
science
major
has
the
following
learning
outcomes:</p
demonstrate
understanding
of
fundamental
concepts
in
marine
science
including
principles
of
geological
physical
chemical
and
biological
processes
in
the
marine
environment.</li
demonstrate
understanding
of
common
laboratory
field
and
modeling
methods
used
in
marine
science.</li
demonstrate
the
ability
to
formulate
falsifiable
hypothesis
ii
design
an
experiment
or
observational
study
to
test
your
hypothesis
iii
analyze
your
results
in
statistically
rigorous
way
and
iv
draw
logical
conclusions
based
on
your
analysis.</li
communicate
effectively
the
concepts
methods
results
and
conclusions
of
marine
science
research
in
oral
and
written
form
to
specialists
and
the
general
public.</li
apply
knowledge
and
skills
learned
to
solve
problems
in
marine
geology
physics
chemistry
or
biology.</li
demonstrate
understanding
of
how
human
activities
impact
the
marine
environment
and
how
the
marine
environment
impacts
human
activities.</li

decision
2?</h4

data
block
key="3n1nd">"Our

key="di032"></p
portrait

data
block
key="fgfn">in
the
new
paper
the

of
mpecs
they

one
shape

looks
like

that

flat

lee
manually

the
flower
into
bud
shape
she

the

c.

the

here

metal
dictated

remembered

shape
the
gel
made

Al3
returned

the
open

Ca2

data
block
key="93r6f">In

data
block
key="d6j00">"It
's
challenging
to
observe
the
dynamics
in
the
rhizosphere
because
it
's
naturally
concealed
beneath
the
opaque
layers
of
soil
says

scholar
reinaldo
alcalde
co
first
author
of
the
new
study
this
was
motivation
to
develop
better
methods
to
image
bacteria
in
these
regions
"</p><p
data
block
key="5kel0">Traditionally
researchers
who
want
to
study
bacterial
dynamics
have
genetically
engineered
bacteria
to
fluoresce
under
laboratory
conditions
their
artificial
green
glow
visible
with
microscope
however
not
all
microbial
species
can
be
engineered
in
this
way
another
method
to
image
bacteria
quantitative
phase
imaging
is
able
to
detect
miniscule
differences
in
transparency
without
the
use
of
fluorescence.</p><p
data
block
key="3qgou">The
new
technology
is
combination
of
these
two
techniques
into
single
optical
setup
called
cfast
complex
field
and
fluorescence
microscopy
using
the
aperture
scanning
technique
the
novel
technique
can
create
three
dimensional
images
of
microbial
communities
much
faster
and
with
less
damage
than
commercial
microscopes.</p><p
data
block
key="64pof">"Through
the
3D
camera
setup
the
two
techniques
work
simultaneously
and
seamlessly
says
postdoctoral
scholar
oumeng
zhang
also
co
first
author
on
the
study.</p><p
data
block
key="a49nh">As
the
work
is
still
proof
of
concept
the
bacterial
communities
were
imaged
outside
of
soil
under
simplified
conditions
the
team
aims
to
continue
developing
and
improving
the
technology
to
be
able
to
precisely
image
roots
and
bacteria
together.</p><p
data
block
key="4mdse">"This

and

idania

rel="nofollow

id="printfriendly
text2
class="pf
button
text">print
friendly</span></a></div></li></ul></aside><div
class="content"><p
from
young
age
idania
rodriguez
understood
just
how
important
it
was
to
be
confident
outspoken
and
to
advocate
for
herself
and
others.</p><p
rodriguez
learned
from
watching
her
parents
fight
to
build
new
life
for
their
three
children
moving
from
puerto
rico
to
tampa
florida
was
nt
an
easy
transition
at
times
her
family
struggled
to
make
ends
meet
but
their
strength
and
perseverance
never
wavered.</p><p
from
their
example
rodriguez
learned
how
to
harness
her
own
voice
and
to
use
it
to
help
people
around
her.</p><p
rodriguez
first
year
carolina
student
founded
the
nonprofit
mental
H2O
when
she
was
inspired
by
the
mental
health
issues
of
her
peers
especially
during
the
COVID-19
pandemic
rodriguez
sought
to
create
an
information
hub
designed
by
youth
for
youth.</p><p
during
school
realized
that
sometimes
mental
health
is
not
really
talked
about
rodriguez
said
there
would
be
students
that
were
struggling
in
silence
or
that
were
afraid
to
come
out
and
say
their
feelings
because
they
were
afraid
of
how
an
adult
would
take
that
information.</p><p
myself
struggled
with
my
own
mental
health
issues
and
realized
that
its
really
difficult
to
receive
help
in
school
that
when
started
to
realize
that
we
had
gap
to
fill
and
if
no
adult
was
going
to
take
stand
knew
that
had
to.</p><p
determined
to
make
difference
rodriguez
pored
over
online
resources
about
mental
health
and
in
the
process
connected
with
fellow
mental
health
advocate
and
current
kenan
flagler
business
school
student
garrett
livingston.</p><p
together
rodriguez
and
livingston
worked
through
the
process
of
registering
mental
H2O
as
501(c)(3
organization
and
creating
website
with
rodriguez
serving
as
president
and
livingston
as
ceo.</p><p
the
mental
H2O
website
started
small
rodriguez
wrote
most
of
the
sites
articles
at
first
coming
home
from
school
around
p.m.
and
working
deep
into
the
evening
before
long
rodriguez
rallied
about
of
her
classmates
to
contribute
then
started
collaborating
with
her
local
school
board
in
hillsborough
county
now
the
site
has
more
than
volunteers
worldwide
and
has
awarded
more
than
1,000
service
hours.</p><p
the
mental
H2O
website
is
filled
with
mental
health
resources
tips
and
tools
all
curated
by
students.</p><p
every
single
resource
on
there
is
actually
created
by
students
for
students
and
were
very
cautious
about
what
we
put
on
the
site
rodriguez
said
know
that
it
can
be
really
difficult
to
receive
help
making
sure
it
is
culturally
sensitive
and
also
addressing
the
needs
of
the
students
was
very
important
from
the
beginning.</p><p
the
work
is
only
getting
started
emboldened
by
the
feedback
she
received
and
the
impact
mental
H2O
has
made
on
her
tampa
community
rodriguez
aims
to
sharpen
her
skills
at
carolina
and
grow
into
even
more
of
leader
in
the
mental
health
space.</p><p
rodriguez
intends
to
apply
to
the
gillings
school
of
global
public
health
and
major
in
health
policy
and
management
she
said
she
chose
to
study
at
carolina
in
part
because
of
the
schools
commitment
to
student
wellness.</p><p
did
nt
want
to
go
to
college
that
did
not
prioritize
student
needs
or
that
did
not
prioritize
student
wellness
rodriguez
said.</p><p
unc
definitely
does
do
that
and
that
why
feel
like
can
drive
bigger
audience
and
can
utilize
what
unc
has
to
offer
to
further
push
my
mission
of
helping
students
with
their
mental
health.</p><div
class="has
social
placeholder

museums
and
Libraries</h1
chances
are
you
will
learn
something
new
every
time
you
enter
yales
exceptional
museums
and
libraries
most
of
them
open
to
the
public
all
of
them
free
of
charge.</p
take
an
exhibition
tour
join
conversation
with
artists
and
curators
in
person
or
online
or
simply
meander
the
extensive
collections
of
paintings
sculptures
historical
items
fossils
and
more
at
your
leisure.</p
the
oldest
college
art
museum
in
north
america
the
gallery
houses
nearly
300,000
objects
from
all
regions
of
the
globe.</p
this
louis
kahn
designed
building
contains
the
largest
collection
of
british
art
outside
the
united
kingdom.</p
the
museum
boasts
renowned
collection
of
over
million
objects
including
fossils
minerals
cultural
items
and
more.</p
the
center
has
nearly
1,000
instruments
that
document
the
history
of
the
worlds
music
traditions.</p
visitors
are
welcome
to
enjoy
historic
spaces
and
curated
exhibits
at
six
locations
each
of
these
locations
also
has
dedicated
special
collections
reading
room
where
researchers
can
request
and
use
rare
unique
or
fragile
materials.</p
sterling
memorial
library
this
cathedral
like
library
houses
three
million
volumes
the
yale
archives
gilmore
music
library
exhibition
galleries
and
more.</p
vast
collectionsfrom
medieval
manuscripts
to
african
american
archives
maps
to
modern
literature
and
moredocument
2,000
years
of
culture.</p
rotunda
of
the
medical
library
the
history
of
medicine
is
captured
in
many
forms
from
medieval
manuscripts
and
early

to
objects
artifacts
and

located
in
farmington
conn.
lewis
walpole
is
one
of

worlds
leading
research
libraries
for
the
study
of
the
long

in
britain.</p
inside

haas
family

and

globe
in

divinitys
collection

yale
has

that
are

equal
opportunity
and
nondiscrimination
at
yale
university:</strong
the
university
is
committed
to
basing
judgments
concerning
the
admission
education
and
employment
of
individuals
upon
their
qualifications
and
abilities
and
affirmatively
seeks
to
attract
to
its
faculty
staff
and
student
body
qualified
persons
of
diverse
backgrounds
university
policy
is
committed
to
affirmative
action
under
law
in
employment
of
women
minority
group
members
individuals
with
disabilities
and
protected
veterans
additionally
in
accordance
with
yales
policy
against
discrimination
and
harassment
and
as
delineated
by
federal
and
connecticut
law
yale
does
not
discriminate
in
admissions
educational
programs
or
employment
against
any
individual
on
account
of
that
individuals
sex
sexual
orientation
gender
identity
or
expression
